snippet: Bill de Blasio, a potential mayoral candidate, wants Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg to determine whether the police stops are warranted and based on reasonable suspicion.
abstract: New York City public advocate Bill de Blasio, possible Democratic contender in the 2013 mayoral race, calls on Mayor Michael R Bloomberg to force a reduction of the New York City Police Department's controversial stop-and-frisk tactic; issue holds great significance for left-leaning and black and Latino voters who can often sway the outcome of the Democratic mayoral primary. Photo (M)

byline.original: By MICHAEL M. GRYNBAUM; Al Baker contributed reporting

lead_paragraph: As the Police Department's stop-and-frisk practice draws increasing criticism from black and Latino New Yorkers, the city's public advocate, Bill de Blasio, said he would call on the mayor to force a reduction of the controversial practice. The proposal, which Mr. de Blasio plans to announce on Wednesday, comes as the stop-and-frisk tactic has emerged as the first major contentious issue of next year's mayoral race. Mr. de Blasio, who is expected to be a candidate, has been among the most outspoken on the topic among the possible Democratic contenders.

headline.main: Public Advocate to Call for Audit of Stop-and-Frisk Tactic
